text: When we talk about different stories that you've written, feel free to give any background information on the story because many of the people listening probably haven't read some of them. And that's always a good way to plug something. They get interested enough in the story to go out and buy it and read it? Right, all right. Try to do that. Okay, okay we'll crank off with a real biggie question here. Okay, how did you get started writing science fiction? Well, there are sort of two versions of that in a way. There's my official writing career, which began after I first got married to Werner Vinci, my now ex-husband. He was a science fiction writer at the time, and I had been a person who fooled around with writing for a while before that. I would just diddle around with it. I used to want to be an artist, and writing was just something I did kind of privately and never showed to anybody and rarely finished anything either, but Werner encouraged me to take it seriously if I was going to write. By that time I'd abandoned wanting to be an artist because my college art professors had ruined my desire to do art. And I was sort of casting about and he knew that I liked to write and so he encouraged me to attempt to take it seriously and sit down and do something and finish it. And so I decided that I would take him up on that. And I started doing a story, which turned out to be the first story that I sold. It was called Tin Soldier. And when I started writing it, I didn't know if I'd ever get it finished or anything, but I did get it finished and I showed it to him and he said he thought it was saleable. And so I started sending it out and I did sell it. After that, I was hooked, of course. I wanted to go on being a writer the bumps are getting the better of us here let me call you back here before I we do our second question see if we can get a better better line on the phone okay I'll call you back in about two to three minutes we'll roll it and try it again let's do a voice test here is the weather still good okay we're not picking up quite as well on this line. No pops, but we're not getting you as well. Well maybe I'll try to speak a little louder, like I remember to speak louder, maybe that'll work out. Yeah that sounds fine, not like that. Okay, we just asked a question on how you guys started writing in science fiction. Okay, what role does your background in anthropology have in your writing? Well actually it does play a pretty big role in the writing because well, I find that anthropology and science fiction have a lot of things in common for me. Archaeology was my specialty and archaeology is the anthropology of the past and science fiction for me is the anthropology of the future. They form sort of a long continuum and the thing I like about both science fiction and anthropology is that they allow you to see how other people do things and that other people's lives are not led the same way yours is and that there are other ways of coping that aren't necessarily the ones you've always known, that other people do things differently and get along perfectly well that way. I love the way that both anthropology and science could take your preconceptions and kind of turn them around 180 degrees and make you say, gee, I've never thought of it like that before. Specifically, I like to use my anthropological background, too, when I'm setting up societies for the stories that I'm going to write. I do sort of an ethnography, which is a cultural study, only I have to make up details of the culture in general instead of just studying an anthropological culture. I do get a lot of details, bits and pieces of interesting societies, which I recombine sometimes to create science fictional societies. It gives you a way of thinking that's very useful when you're writing a science fiction story, looking for different ways, hoping that when you send your rocket ship out into the galaxy it's not going to come to a planet where everyone acts like 1950s Earth. You know, I really enjoy exploring differences in societies and things like that. And, well, mythology is kind of an offshoot of science fiction that I, or whoops, mythology is an offshoot of anthropology that I find is very useful to science fiction, too. I get a lot of story ideas from mythology and a lot of I think just kind of underlying strengths that are almost like fantasy and I like to weave them into the science fiction which is what I most like to write and I think it gives them a stronger appeal possibly being we all have sort of a common background of folktales and myths and by interweaving those in your stories, you sort of either reinforce or maybe update some of the old basic stories that our culture is based on. Right, yeah, I think very much so. I think there really are certain universalities in this, too, which kind of strike everybody at a very deep and basic level. And if you could capture some of that same feeling in a story when you write it, And maybe by employing elements consciously or unconsciously of, you know, out of mythology, I think that you can really have a very deep emotional impact on the reader, which I think is probably what every writer would like to do. All right-y. Let's see here. You already answered one of my other questions, so we'll... Uh, now we'll go ahead and add on it here. Continuing on your use of folk tales and stuff, all of your stories that I've read seem to have a happy ending of sorts. Is that sort of based on, most folktales have happy endings. Is that because your stories have a basis in folktales or that you're more or less basically an optimistic person? I think it's more that I'm basically an optimistic person. Actually not every single one of my stories is based on a foalt bet. A lot of them do have those elements in them but some don't. It's just that I really hate to leave a story feeling totally depressed by it so I think I hate to write a story that's totally depressing. Frequently I think the stories have sort of bittersweet endings where people don't walk off hand in hand into the sunset. They're usually dragging along a few suitcases full of problems, too. I think the way life is, it's unrealistic, usually, to write a totally happy ending. But I do like to have an optimistic ending. When I read things, I relate to them on a very personal level. I get very involved in a story. And if it's a story, the end result of which is to make me feel totally depressed and feel like, you know, why bother to live? I really don't like being left feeling that way, and I think I don't like feeling that way when I write, too. Yes, you seem to get very involved with the characters you create also. Is this because you flesh them out so well when you're writing them, or is it because your characters are sort of variations on yourself? Well, I think probably some of both. I think a lot of my favorite characters are, you know, bits and pieces of me. I don't know that any one of them is all me. I think all people have different aspects of their personality which come to the fore at different times just in their day-to-day life. And I think when you're writing, you can't help but inject those personalities into characters. I really do like characters in stories. I like to read about characters who seem real. and so I like to try and make my own characters as real as possible when I write them, and I think, you know, by getting inside their heads, I invariably, you know, stick a few of my thoughts in there. I do have some characters who are based on other people I know and things like that, too, but I do like to, I like to, you know, well, when I write about strange things and new ideas and different societies, I like to put people who are recognizably human, even if they're aliens, I suppose, but people that the reader can relate to into those situations and let the reader see how the human being reacts to the strange set of circumstances. It's not simply the strange set of circumstances which interests me, although that's, I think, why I write science fiction, because I don't like to write about the same old day-to-day thing. I like to explore new ground. but I like to do it with actual characters who come as close as possible to seem like real people. I like to see what they do in given circumstances. Siarett Sarabneh I might like to talk more about the future. Science fiction is the only literature which allows you to speculate about the future, so it does open up a lot of vistas that can't be explored in what we call mainstream literature. Maura Right. Yes, that's really what I like about science fiction. But I read my first science fiction book when I was in ninth grade. And I just felt like, you know, boy, where has this been all my life? I was just swept away by it. And I felt like I really hardly wanted to read anything but science fiction after that. It was just so exciting to me too. These new worlds opened up to me. Yeah, okay, that's... We're getting to a... Here's a story question. Okay. Dealing with Crystal Ship and Eyes of Amber. In two of your stories, The Crystal Ship and the Eyes of Amber, you've explored the positive and negative aspects of a highly developed technological culture, making contact with a more primitive culture. Were you sort of extrapolating on contemporary aid or exploitation of world powers by lesser developed nations? or is this more like when archaeologists or anthropologists uncover some of the more primitive tribes in Africa and Australia, some of the things that happened to them? Well, actually, part of that question slightly confuses me. did you mean that more advanced cultures being, more technically advanced cultures being exploited by less advanced cultures or vice versa? Vice versa. Let me back up. Like in Crystal Ship, you have the extremely advanced culture on the planet with the, I can't remember the name of the race of the aliens. I don't either right now. Well, good. You don't feel as bad. They come and they take over their planet. They start exploiting the aliens, and then the aliens give them that drug, which sends them off into Never Never Land. Of course, their super advanced civilization collapses underneath them. But you take the other side of the coin, and Eyes of Amber, you have the highly advanced civilization on Earth helping the race on Titan through the use of the satellite that they landed on Titan. And the question, what was my question here? Let me find it again. Was that you have taken both the positive aspect in Eyes of Amber and the negative aspect in Crystal Ship, and was that sort of an extrapolation on either anthropological discoveries of ancient cultures, some of those found in Australia or Africa, are the exploitation that the world powers have done of lesser developed third and fourth world countries. Well, gee, some of both of those, I suppose, and just kind of my general awareness of history you know frequently at least recent history it's frequently been the case that you know more technologically advanced cultures decide to spread out into territories in which the people are living at a lower level of cultural development and they feel you know I think the original justification in Utopia by Thomas Moore was that these people weren't making proper use of the land. Therefore we should take it away from them and use it ourselves. I think that there's going to be some sort of chaotic reaction whenever two societies meet. Well, even two societies on a similar level frequently wind up fighting it out. But societies on a different level are going to collide and create a lot of culture shock. And it's going to change at least the less advanced society forever. Sometimes it has effects on the more advanced society, too. Frequently, the more advanced society is so kind of sublime in its arrogance that it really is frequently impervious to the values of the less developed society. You know, seeing itself as morally superior and bringing, you know, salvation to these poor, dirty wretches. And, you know, I find that attitude rather intolerable although I think that by the same token I think that there are things which the advanced society can offer to the less developed society, primarily things like better medical care and better farming methods and things like that frequently, which can be very beneficial to the people in the less developed society, but it's exploring the different factors and different possibilities there and seeing what happens, you know, what is the potential for both good and evil in the situation. I think it's the drama of the situation that appeals to me. I can't help but make certain moral judgments when I write, you know, when I set up a certain situation like the situation in The Crystal Ship where, you know, the arrogant society does in fact get its comeuppance, which rarely happens usually in human history. I think I was sort of operating off of the idea of how European settlers had come and essentially arrested all of the North and South American continents from the Indians, basically, and had not done much in return but wiped them out, and the Indians had been essentially, for the most part, defenseless in the long run against this. I had been thinking about how the Indians had introduced the Europeans to tobacco, which is today a fairly significant health problem, not on the same level as wiping out the entire society. But I think that my thought from this was, what if they had introduced something to the Europeans, which was incredibly destructive to them, if they had brought smallpox to the Europeans instead of vice versa, what would have been the outcome of that situation? I think that was what I was playing around with at Crystal Ship. I guess in Eyes of Amper was the idea that, you know, useful values or useful items even can be introduced into a culture by another culture, and that the effects not necessarily have to be bad. But then at the same time in that story, you also have the exploitive element, which you get in things like as you were saying the modern day anthropologists barging in on some here before undisturbed Stone Age tribe and putting them all on national television and just totally disrupting their environment when they really have no business doing anything like that. Yes. Very good answer. And it's getting worse. We're going to edit out all the thoroughgoes. Oh yeah. yeah, we can whack those out. In fact, if you'd like to get a drink of water or something, we can pause for just a moment. Okay, you mentioned, I'm gonna take part of this, I'm gonna elaborate on your mention of Eyes of Amber and go on to a question on music in your stories. No. Okay. In eyes of Amber, the protagonist is a musician, a songwriter, and it seems that music seems to play an important role in your writing. Yes it really does actually, I seem to relate to music on a kind of subliminal level I guess, something that operates something like mythology for me when I hear a song I frequently get down into the song and start wondering what's going on in the background of it you know the situation that's set up in the song leads me to think well who are the people involved in this and how did they get here and what is this talking about actually I tend to relate to songs in a very personal way they have a kind of reality about them I frequently can't help thinking that the songwriter must have written that about his or her own experience, even though I know it's no more likely that they did than that someone writing fiction necessarily wrote a story about their own life. But I just enjoy music tremendously and it really stimulates creative juices for me. So I frequently do wind up being inspired to write certain things by listening to music. In fact, Eyes of Amber, the title of that stories. Take it from a song by Buffy Saint Marie, which is about someone who has a demon lover and fit into the context of the story where the alien woman thinks of the space probe as a demon and she relates to it because it does respond to her. Although she doesn't know it's the human beings on Earth, she relates to it as another being and has this kind of fascination for it. It is just taking little elements like that and working them into stories. It is one of the pleasures of writing for me. I pause after each one of your questions because the machine and the equipment that we have is designed for recording an incoming signal. And whenever I talk, it records it, but it's distorted and loud and all sorts of garbage in it. So we rerecord the questions and then edit them in. My questions will be the same questions, as far as content goes, but they will probably be worded better than the ones I'm actually giving you, and they will match your answers, which will make both of us sound really smart. Sounds great. I have no idea there are so much technical complexity involved in this. Usually, when I do interviews, they usually wind up in the studio, you know, wind up doing them when I'm on the spot or something like that. It's very interesting to hear about everything that goes on at the end, actually. Yeah. Yeah, we figured with the radio program, of course, a lot of it's left to your imagination, and we have the distinct advantage of not having to represent any sort of visual image and that we can just crank up and call up somebody, and talk to them over the phone and record it, and then we process all the sounds in order to get the telephone noise off the line, and edit it all together and put together a program. So, it's got some good advantage and some distinct advantages to it. It cuts our travel budget way down. Right. Okay, this one is going to be a question about your your future history, which it seems that you either seem to be developing or that you have developed. Okay. That being the Outcast of Heaven's Belt, Legacy, and Media Man, and possibly some other stories which I haven't read which might belong to that. No, actually, I think there are only two things. Okay. But, okay, here's the question. You've tackled one of the more difficult types of science fiction, that being future history, as in The Outcast of Heaven's Belt, Legacy, and Media Man. All the stories having a common background. How did your future history get started? Well, actually, the future history kind of belongs to my ex-husband, to tell you the truth. The idea of the situation in the outcast of Heaven's Belt, which was the original thing that I wrote in what turned out to be that future history, was the idea of a solar system. Another system where there was no Earth-like planet, but only an asteroid belt and some gas giant planets, where if you had a high enough technology level, then you could survive there in a very luxurious way, but if you ever lost the technological level, you had no Earth-like planet to retreat to, or you didn't have to manufacture your own air and water and things like that. below a certain level of technological development, you were doomed. This basic idea had been one that Werner had, and he was not actively writing at that time. He teaches at San Diego State University, and he was ensconced at the process of getting his tenure and things like that. so I was the writer in the family, and he was kind of sublimating, I guess, by helping me work with my writing, and I was at a loss for an idea at one point, and he said, well, I have this idea if you want to write a story about it, so I wound up writing Outcasts of Heaven and Death about this society, and then I got the idea for the story Media Man later on. Well, I was still in the process of doing the novel, actually, because I started making it as a novella, and then I decided that it was not sufficiently fleshed out, and I had to make it into a novel. But in the midst of all that, I got the idea for Media Man, which was from a very ordinary everyday idea, which I wanted to do, you know, to take, was the sort of the hero and the villain trapped in the middle of nowhere. And how do you get out of it alive? I decided I wanted to take that particular situation and make a science fiction story around it. and when I started thinking about it I realized that the media man the sort of combination of uh of ad man and newsman which populates the the Demarchy which is one of the societies and heaven belt um that being the asteroid belt in the story after that the media man was the perfect sort of person to put into this situation and it was one of the few stories where just about everything the story kind of fell into place at once for me I realized that it just fits just perfectly into the same future history as the novel did. So far I have been doing a lot of different histories, actually. I take a lot of different stories which take place in different futures. I've just been having fun kind of playing around with that and having a lot of different societies. But I look upon each one of those possible futures as developing into a separate future history because if I ever find another story that fits in to that mode, like with Tin Soldier if I ever find another story that seems to fit perfectly with a group of women spacers I will write another story in that future history so far the Heaven Belt Future History is the only one that has actually produced more than one story Legacy is actually an expansion of Media Man which combines Media Man and a sequel to Media Man both of which are prequels and it's very complicated but I do look forward to writing more things in that future history. I'd like to write about more about the planet Morningside which is also involved in the story in Outcast of Heaven, because I got a lot more background about that planet which I didn't really get to use in the novel and I'd like to write more about that sometime and the mission that we were able to present, so I had to look back to him. I had to take that back to him. Oh, okay. Very good. I have only scanned part of Outcast of Heaven's Belt. Is Morningside the planet that the starship comes from? Right. Okay. Oh, yeah, by the way, I did get Snow Queen. Oh, you did? Yeah, we found it in Dallas, and they shipped it to us so I I have read about half of it reading rapidly along along reading everything else at the same time and trying not to get them confused but I have a gigantic question about snow queen which you can feel free to cut short or talk about for the next day or whatever here's an interjection question I don't think I've asked you this but I haven't asked you a question about how you construct aliens have i how i do what construct your aliens oh no okay good that's a good question here we go okay um i'll probably move this back up uh and to the part where you were talking where we were talking about crystal ship and eyes of amber okay but uh since you do have a rather good background in anthropology uh how do you go about constructing your aliens Oh, that's an interesting question, actually. I don't think I have any particular method for constructing aliens. They frequently kind of arise out of other givens in the situation and out of the environment. In Eyes of Amber, the aliens, although they seemed superficially humanoid, were actually constructed for an entirely different nitrogen-breathing situation on a world in one of the noons of Saturn, a world which was extremely cold, and they were tri-phibians which meant that they spent part of the time in the sky, part of the land, part of the water. The creatures in Crystal Ship were sort of marsupial like, and the creatures in My story to Belle, the cat thrived on radiation. They just lived on pure radiation. They lived in essentially an incredibly radioactively hot swamp on a planet hidden away in a cave, but there's actually no real pattern to any of them. The creatures living in the cave came out of the idea of there being essentially natural nuclear reactors forming on the earth. Because there was an article somewhere about how there seemed to be the fossil remains of one somewhere in Africa, I think. It seemed that at some point a concentration of ore had gotten so radioactively hot that it had actually started a thermonuclear reaction. Not a bomb, but just a roiling, boiling situation. And so it had these creatures that had come from whole planets like that, and had been shipwrecked, essentially, on this planet, which would be normal to human beings. And they had managed to find this spot and take refuge in it. And that was just... It came out of trying to think of what sort of creatures would live in that environment. I suppose I must in general start with the environment and then try to think about what sort of adaptations would be necessary to it. I don't know. So aliens are one of those things that just sort of spring out of the unconscious, I guess. I don't really have a pattern for creating them except that I start with certain givens of the culture. One of the problems with creating aliens is that if you make them too alien, then the reader can't understand them or relate to them, and they just seem to be essentially nonsensical. It's very difficult to try to convey a feeling of alienness, and yet something that a human being can still relate to and not simply say, what is this junk? I don't understand this. Stop reading books. A lot of science fiction writers have talked about that. There are frequently accusations about, well, the aliens are not really alien enough, but then you come down to the old bottom line that if they are alien enough, even if one human being can imagine something that alien, someone else may not be able to understand it. and so you're always caught in the light when you're writing about aliens. Yes, and to Belle the cat, you have created one of the, if you'll pardon a pun or whatever, you seem to have created one of the most alien aliens I've read about. How did you come up with the idea of, the being as I understand it, the mind or the intelligence of the creature is down hidden away in the cave, and it either creates or controls its mobile parts, the little creatures. But its thought processes were amazing. What did you go through to come up with that? Oh, this reminds me of a story about Robert Browning. A woman asked him one time what one of his poems meant, and he said, Madam, when I wrote that, only God and I knew what it meant. and now only God knows. I can't actually remember how it came up with that idea. It's terrible. I don't know whether it's in my notes anywhere or not. I think it must have grown, kind of grown out of the idea of specialization in animals where, you know, a human being is, biologically speaking, a very unspecialized creature because it has fingernails, which are the most primitive form of things, as opposed to a claw or hoof, which are adaptations, specializations of nails. There are various other things about the human body which are, quote, primitive biologically. And I guess I may have been thinking about specialization developing to an extreme where actual different parts of the body became separate entities and they were all controlled by the mind, which stayed in one spot. some of the specialized parts were particularly strong and some were particularly agile, things like that, and they could be sent out kind of far-ranging and controlled telepathically by the brain, which just stayed at home in safety, and there were essentially two levels of organism which made up one creature, and the specialized creatures that the brain controlled had no particular brain of their own, except for a rudimentary receiver so that it could send them its commands and could receive back from various impressions of what they were doing. I wound up, the way they communicate became, it was sort of like writing poetry for me. I used to like to write poetry, and this came as close to me as I had for a long time. And then while the brain creatures were communicating with each other, with the other brains and discussing their plight, they were at the same time receiving input and sending directions to all their mobiles, their little specialized parts that were moving around the radioactive muck. And so you would get their basic commentary and then all the levels below that of interaction. And I really enjoyed writing about that. I thought it was quite exciting when I was doing it. But the trouble is that I think I only found one person who actually understood, without having it explained to them, what was going on in that story. Almost no one else understood, and I felt like that was the case where my aliens had gotten too alien for their own good. It was sort of frustrating in a way, but, you know, I'm not sorry I did it, actually. It was a fascinating exercise for me. Yeah, well, you found two. Uh, Daryl, did you understand? Three. Okay, you found three. Oh, right! Okay, now this is the question on Snow Queen. Okay. Okay, and feel free to elaborate or whatever you want to do without giving away the plot. Well, to give away the plot would take me four or five hours. Oh, okay, good, we don't have that much time. Especially because I haven't finished it yet and I want to find out how it ends. I'll try not to let the endings slip. But, okay. You've undertaken another difficult writing task, that being world-building in your novel, The Snow Queen. It's a wonderful work of science fantasy. Would you call it science fantasy? I suppose so, actually. It is, you know, in its heart, it's a science fiction story, but it does have heavy mythological elements, which I think give it a fantasy-like quality. And I wasn't fighting that at all. I was striving for a sort of fusion. MR. I think you get it. Okay. Here's the rest of the question. Let me back up here. It has a wonderful work of science fantasy with a very involved plot and a very exciting narrative. This must have taken a tremendous amount of background material to develop this novel. oh well yes probably uh oh gosh that that book was it was quite an incredible thing for me to write that book because i i wound up being about it was over 600 pages of manuscript it's almost 200,000 words long and uh when i started writing it i had never written a complete novel all at once with Outcast of Heaven Belts. I had written a novella, and then I had increased in size to that of a novel. And I was feeling kind of daunted about the very idea of writing a normal, what I thought would be a normal-length novel of about 200 pages. But I finally did sit down and start to write it. And the more I wrote, the more I realized that it was not going to to stop at 200 pages, I think I had gotten through a hundred pages and realized that I had barely gotten into the plot at all, my writing and from then on I could only just go on and write and write and write and see where it led me. It got more and more complicated as it went along until I really despaired at times that I would ever be able to finish the thing. It was a great comfort to me when I finally sat down and figured out how everything had to fit together to get to the end of the book. Okay, I did a fair amount of background work beforehand, but actually I wound up doing a great deal of the work, I think, during the process of writing the book. I conceived of the idea of the Wicked City of Carbuncle, which gets its name because it's either a jewel or a fester, depending on your point of view. But I wanted it to be sort of a place where all kinds of cultures from all kinds of worlds came together and mixed and mingled and in trying to make a portrait of the city I needed a lot of different characters with a lot of different backgrounds behind them. And so whenever I needed a new character I would write one into the story and then I'd kind of have to figure out where they came from. Frequently I don't lay everything out before I actually start to write a book. I have kind of a basic structure which I think it was being sort of like a trellis and then the story is a line that grows up through it and fills it in and flushes it out and things. And I think because I didn't have any idea of how big the snow clean was going to be, it got even more complex in the process than most of the things. Most of the things I have a clearer idea ahead of time of what they're going to be about, but it was just so massive it was impossible to think about everything ahead of time. It was mostly the scientific research, I think, that I did ahead of time and reading up on black holes and things like that. I regret that black holes and clones became such kind of stereotypes during the time in which I was reading the book. They were not quite such archetypal sci-fi clichés when I started writing the book as they are now. But at least since I hope the book will appeal to a wide audience, that it's at least, maybe people who don't even regularly read science fiction will know what I'm talking about, and I talk about black holes and clones at this point. But I did do a fair amount of technical reading or semi-technical reading on the nature of black holes and using them as means of travel in order to set up the basic science fictional premises of the book. And I did, I happened to read Robert Graves' book, The White Goddess, just before I started writing The Snow Queen. And that, I found that influenced me heavily in that I got a lot of the mythical fantasy-type elements out of that and kind of wove them into the texture of the book. And I tried to create societies which would kind of fit in with both technical and non-technical societies, which would fit comfortably with kind of the underlying themes and premises of the book. And from there, things just growed like Tompsey, I guess. One of the characters who comes from a very advanced society, the most technologically dominant society in the book, started out as a walk-on character. His name is Gundolino, and he came along with one of the major characters in the book, in the scene, and he just started acting up. And out of his personality, I kind of saw a whole cultural stereotype growing. And I realized part of, actually part of where he came from was that I had been reading a lot of books about, I've been reading some fiction books about Romans in Britain, because I've always been fascinated by Romans in Britain as part of the archaeology thing, I guess. and just the kind of fascination was the sort of science-fictional reversal where the highly cultured people are the people who too often wind up in sword and sorcery fantasies, the kind of dark and swarthy people and they're usually squelching around in the bushes but they were the people who were suave and sophisticated and non-top and the people with red hair and freckles and green eyes were running around like howling barbarians in the brush, and I thought that was a delightful twist. Thinking about this and about cultural arrogance and how the Romans sort of resembled the Victorian English in that way, I just got into a mindset to write about that sort of a character, I think. And so, you know, without even realizing this particular character just began taking on all these aspects, and out of him I realized what his whole culture must be like and it became one of the important societies in the book. Just odd little things happened like that. The whole book kind of grew up in a strange way. It was quite an indescribable thing, and if I'd known ahead of time what I was getting into, I would never have started it. Probably just as well that we can't see the future, I think. Correct me if I'm wrong. I believe I read somewhere that you had some, is some part of that novel based upon the Hans Christian Andersen story, Snow Queen? Oh, yes, it is. As a matter of fact, that was my original inspiration for the book. There's a cartoon and animated movie of the Snow Queen, which they occasionally show on television. If you can wait through 15 minutes of Art Linkletter talking to children at the beginning of it, it's really quite well done. I was interested in it, you know, I had first seen that movie when I was in about 8th grade and thought, oh this is silly. But when I saw it again, back during the 70s sometime, I realized what an interesting fairy tale it is. It's most fairy tales, the thing about most fairy tales is that they are frequently degenerate mythology. And if you know any particular amount about Near Eastern and European mythology, you see a lot of symbolic archetypes you see ravens and stags and and the wicked stepmother and the sweet young innocent and things like that which you know they they all actually have their archetypes back in um in european and near eastern mythology and that well that just as an aside that was why The Robert Graves book on the white goddess and on all that mythology in Europe and the New East fit in so perfectly with this particular story that Hans Christian Andersen had written down, but was essentially one of these old tales, which are kind of twisted-up mythology. And the thing that interested me especially about this particular tale was that there was no prince in it. And it's usually Prince who gets to do all the fun and exciting things like fighting the dragons and things like that. And waking up the sleeping maiden and the women in the story are usually either the wicked old witch or some helpless simpler and creature. And, you know, I get sort of bored with that kind of thing. But I was very interested, this book was quite a twist because, or this fairy tale was quite a twist because all the main roles in it were played by women. The basic idea of the story is that there are a little girl and a little boy who are friends, and the little boy is stolen away by the Snow Queen, who is kind of an elemental goddess of winter. And most of the story concerns the little girl's travels as she's searching for him and all the people she meets. And the people she meets are virtually all female, and the people in positions of power in the story are women. And I thought that was quite interesting and unique. and I was in the mood to do a story in which women played major roles in the book. And so I thought that was a good jumping off point for it. And so from there, everything else just started growing, basically. I read Robert Graves' book and I said, Boy, this gives me a lot more fuel for the fire, and I just started writing at that point. I didn't want to write a fantasy, though. I didn't want to just make it a retelling of the fairy tale, basically. I really wanted it to be a whole new story, and I wanted it to be science fiction as well because that's just the way my brain works, I guess. I have written a couple of fantasy stories recently, and I've always enjoyed reading fantasy as well as science fiction, but so far the majority of my work has been at least technically science fiction. Oh, you answered my next question. Did you have any fantasy stories on the back burner? Okay, you already took care of that one. All right. We've pretty well rolled through.

segments.text: When we talk about different stories that you've written, feel free to give any
background information on the story because many of the people listening
probably haven't read some of them. And that's always a good way to plug
something. They get interested enough in the story to go out and buy it and read it?
Right, all right. Try to do that.
Okay, okay we'll crank
off with a real biggie question here. Okay, how did you get started writing
science fiction? Well, there are sort of two versions of that in a way. There's my
official writing career, which began after I first got married to Werner Vinci, my now
ex-husband. He was a science fiction writer at the time, and I had been a person who fooled
around with writing for a while before that. I would just diddle around with it. I used
to want to be an artist, and writing was just something I did kind of privately and never
showed to anybody and rarely finished anything either, but Werner encouraged me to take it
seriously if I was going to write. By that time I'd abandoned wanting to be an artist because my
college art professors had ruined my desire to do art. And I was sort of casting about and he knew
that I liked to write and so he encouraged me to attempt to take it seriously and sit down and do
something and finish it. And so I decided that I would take him up on that. And I started doing
a story, which turned out to be the first story that I sold. It was called Tin Soldier. And when
I started writing it, I didn't know if I'd ever get it finished or anything, but I did get it
finished and I showed it to him and he said he thought it was saleable. And so I started sending
it out and I did sell it. After that, I was hooked, of course. I wanted to go on being a writer
the bumps are getting the better of us here let me call you back here before I

okay I'll call you back in about two to three minutes we'll roll it and try it

Well maybe I'll try to speak a little louder, like I remember to speak louder,
maybe that'll work out. Yeah that sounds fine, not like that. Okay, we just asked a
question on how you guys started writing in science fiction. Okay, what role does
your background in anthropology have in your writing? Well actually it does play
a pretty big role in the writing because
well, I find that anthropology
and science fiction have a lot of things in common
for me. Archaeology
was my specialty and archaeology
is the anthropology of the past
and science fiction for me is the anthropology
of the future. They form sort of
a long continuum
and the thing I like
about both science fiction and anthropology
is that they allow you to
see how other people do things
and that other people's lives
are not led the same way yours is
and that there are other ways of coping
that aren't necessarily the ones you've always known,
that other people do things differently
and get along perfectly well that way.
I love the way that both anthropology and science
could take your preconceptions
and kind of turn them around 180 degrees
and make you say,
gee, I've never thought of it like that before.
Specifically, I like to use my anthropological background, too,
when I'm setting up societies for the stories
that I'm going to write.
I do sort of an ethnography, which is a cultural study,
only I have to make up details of the culture in general
instead of just studying an anthropological culture.
I do get a lot of details, bits and pieces
of interesting societies, which I recombine sometimes
to create science fictional societies.
It gives you a way of thinking that's very useful when you're writing a science fiction story,
looking for different ways, hoping that when you send your rocket ship out into the galaxy
it's not going to come to a planet where everyone acts like 1950s Earth.
You know, I really enjoy exploring differences in societies and things like that.
And, well, mythology is kind of an offshoot of science fiction that I,
or whoops, mythology is an offshoot of anthropology that I find is very useful
to science fiction, too.
I get a lot of
story ideas from
mythology and a lot of
I think just kind of
underlying strengths
that are almost like fantasy
and I like to weave them into the science fiction

and I think it gives them
a stronger appeal
possibly being
we all have sort of a common background
of folktales and myths
and by interweaving those in your stories,
you sort of either reinforce or maybe update
some of the old basic stories that our culture is based on.
Right, yeah, I think very much so.
I think there really are certain universalities in this, too,
which kind of strike everybody at a very deep and basic level.
And if you could capture some of that same feeling
in a story when you write it,
And maybe by employing elements consciously or unconsciously of, you know, out of mythology,
I think that you can really have a very deep emotional impact on the reader,
which I think is probably what every writer would like to do.
All right-y.
Let's see here.
You already answered one of my other questions, so we'll...

Continuing on your use of folk tales and stuff,
all of your stories that I've read
seem to have a happy ending of sorts.
Is that sort of based on, most folktales have happy endings.
Is that because your stories have a basis in folktales
or that you're more or less basically an optimistic person?
I think it's more that I'm
basically an optimistic person.
Actually not every single

I think the stories have
sort of bittersweet endings
where people don't walk off hand in hand
into the sunset. They're usually
dragging along a few suitcases full of problems, too.
I think the way life is, it's unrealistic, usually,
to write a totally happy ending.
But I do like to have an optimistic ending.
When I read things, I relate to them on a very personal level.
I get very involved in a story.
And if it's a story, the end result of which
is to make me feel totally depressed
and feel like, you know, why bother to live?
I really don't like being left feeling that way,
and I think I don't like feeling that way when I write, too.
Yes, you seem to get very involved with the characters you create also.
Is this because you flesh them out so well when you're writing them,
or is it because your characters are sort of variations on yourself?
Well, I think probably some of both.
I think a lot of my favorite characters are, you know, bits and pieces of me.
I don't know that any one of them is all me.
I think all people have different aspects of their personality
which come to the fore at different times just in their day-to-day life.
And I think when you're writing, you can't help but inject those personalities into characters.
I really do like characters in stories.
I like to read about characters who seem real.
and so I like to try and make my own characters as real as possible when I write them,
and I think, you know, by getting inside their heads,
I invariably, you know, stick a few of my thoughts in there.
I do have some characters who are based on other people I know and things like that, too,
but I do like to, I like to, you know,
well, when I write about strange things and new ideas and different societies,
I like to put people who are recognizably human, even if they're aliens, I suppose,
but people that the reader can relate to into those situations
and let the reader see how the human being reacts to the strange set of circumstances.
It's not simply the strange set of circumstances which interests me,
although that's, I think, why I write science fiction,
because I don't like to write about the same old day-to-day thing.
I like to explore new ground.
but I like to do it with actual characters who come as close as possible to seem like
real people.
I like to see what they do in given circumstances.
Siarett Sarabneh I might like to talk more about the future.
Science fiction is the only literature which allows you to speculate about the future,
so it does open up a lot of vistas that can't be explored in what we call mainstream literature.
Maura Right.
Yes, that's really what I like about science fiction.
But I read my first science fiction book when I was in ninth grade.
And I just felt like, you know, boy, where has this been all my life?
I was just swept away by it.
And I felt like I really hardly wanted to read anything but science fiction after that.
It was just so exciting to me too.
These new worlds opened up to me.

Another system where there was no Earth-like planet, but only an asteroid belt and some gas giant planets,
where if you had a high enough technology level, then you could survive there in a very luxurious way,
but if you ever lost the technological level, you had no Earth-like planet to retreat to,
or you didn't have to manufacture your own air and water and things like that.
below a certain level of technological development, you were doomed.
This basic idea had been one that Werner had, and he was not actively writing at that time.

so I was the writer in the family,

Oh, that's an interesting question, actually.
I don't think I have any particular method for constructing aliens.
They frequently kind of arise out of other givens in the situation and out of the environment.
In Eyes of Amber, the aliens, although they seemed superficially humanoid,
were actually constructed for an entirely different nitrogen-breathing
situation on a world
in one of the
noons of
Saturn, a world which was extremely
cold, and
they were tri-phibians
which meant that they spent part
of the time in the sky, part of the land,
part of the water.
The creatures in
Crystal Ship were sort of marsupial
like, and
the creatures in
My story to Belle, the cat thrived on radiation.
They just lived on pure radiation.
They lived in essentially an incredibly radioactively hot swamp
on a planet hidden away in a cave,
but there's actually no real pattern to any of them.
The creatures living in the cave came out of the idea
of there being essentially natural nuclear reactors
forming on the earth.
Because there was an article somewhere about how there seemed to be the fossil remains of one somewhere in Africa, I think.
It seemed that at some point a concentration of ore had gotten so radioactively hot that it had actually started a thermonuclear reaction.
Not a bomb, but just a roiling, boiling situation.
And so it had these creatures that had come from whole planets like that,
and had been shipwrecked, essentially, on this planet,
which would be normal to human beings.
And they had managed to find this spot and take refuge in it.
And that was just...
It came out of trying to think of what sort of creatures would live in that environment.
I suppose I must in general start with the environment
and then try to think about what sort of adaptations would be necessary to it.
I don't know.
So aliens are one of those things that just sort of spring out of the unconscious, I guess.
I don't really have a pattern for creating them except that I start with certain givens of the culture.
One of the problems with creating aliens is that if you make them too alien,
then the reader can't understand them or relate to them,
and they just seem to be essentially nonsensical.
It's very difficult to try to convey a feeling of alienness,
and yet something that a human being can still relate to
and not simply say,
what is this junk?
I don't understand this.
Stop reading books.
A lot of science fiction writers have talked about that.
There are frequently accusations about,
well, the aliens are not really alien enough,
but then you come down to the old bottom line
that if they are alien enough,
even if one human being can imagine something that alien,
someone else may not be able to understand it.
and so you're always caught in the light when you're writing about aliens.
Yes, and to Belle the cat, you have created one of the, if you'll pardon a pun or whatever,
you seem to have created one of the most alien aliens I've read about.
How did you come up with the idea of, the being as I understand it,
the mind or the intelligence of the creature is down hidden away in the cave,
and it either creates or controls its mobile parts, the little creatures.
But its thought processes were amazing.
What did you go through to come up with that?
Oh, this reminds me of a story about Robert Browning.
A woman asked him one time what one of his poems meant,
and he said, Madam, when I wrote that, only God and I knew what it meant.
and now only God knows.
I can't actually remember how it came up with that idea.
It's terrible.
I don't know whether it's in my notes anywhere or not.
I think it must have grown,
kind of grown out of the idea of specialization in animals
where, you know, a human being is, biologically speaking,
a very unspecialized creature because it has fingernails,
which are the most primitive form of things,
as opposed to a claw or hoof,
which are adaptations, specializations of nails.
There are various other things about the human body
which are, quote, primitive biologically.
And I guess I may have been thinking about specialization
developing to an extreme where actual different parts of the body
became separate entities and they were all controlled by the mind,
which stayed in one spot.
some of the specialized parts were particularly strong
and some were particularly agile, things like that,
and they could be sent out kind of far-ranging
and controlled telepathically by the brain,
which just stayed at home in safety,
and there were essentially two levels of organism
which made up one creature,
and the specialized creatures that the brain controlled
had no particular brain of their own,
except for a rudimentary receiver
so that it could send them its commands
and could receive back from various impressions
of what they were doing.
I wound up, the way they communicate became,
it was sort of like writing poetry for me.
I used to like to write poetry,
and this came as close to me as I had for a long time.
And then while the brain creatures
were communicating with each other,
with the other brains and discussing their plight,
they were at the same time receiving input and sending
directions to all their mobiles, their little specialized
parts that were moving around the radioactive muck.
And so you would get their basic commentary
and then all the levels below that of interaction.
And I really enjoyed writing about that.
I thought it was quite exciting when I was doing it.
But the trouble is that I think I only found one person who actually understood,
without having it explained to them, what was going on in that story.
Almost no one else understood, and I felt like that was the case
where my aliens had gotten too alien for their own good.
It was sort of frustrating in a way, but, you know, I'm not sorry I did it, actually.
